message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin works by forming intrastrand and interstrand cross-links in DNA, leading to DNA damage and apoptosis. It does not inhibit polymerization of tubulin (option A) or inhibit topoisomerase 2 (option B). Free radical-mediated lipid peroxidation (option D) is not a mechanism of action for cisplatin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin is a platinum-containing chemotherapy drug that forms covalent DNA adducts, which leads to the formation of interstrand DNA cross-links. This can cause DNA damage and ultimately lead to cell death in rapidly dividing cancer cells. None of the other options are associated with the mechanism of action of cisplatin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The drug being used is cisplatin, which forms intrastrand and interstrand DNA cross-links to prevent DNA replication and transcription, thereby inhibiting cancer cell growth. Options A and B refer to different classes of chemotherapy drugs, while option D describes the mechanism of action of radiation therapy, not chemotherapy.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin is known to form interstrand DNA cross-links, which ultimately leads to apoptosis of cancer cells. The other options are mechanisms of action for different antineoplastic drugs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin causes interstrand DNA cross-links, which inhibit DNA replication and transcription, resulting in cell death. This is a common mechanism of action for platinum-based chemotherapy drugs such as cisplatin. Option (A) refers to drugs that inhibit microtubule formation, (B) refers to drugs that inhibit topoisomerases, and (D) refers to drugs that generate free radicals that cause damage to cancer cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin works by forming interstrand DNA cross-links, which prevent DNA replication and transcription, ultimately leading to cancer cell death. The other options, such as inhibition of tubulin polymerization or topoisomerase 2, are mechanisms of action for other antineoplastic drugs. Free radical-mediated lipid peroxidation is not a mechanism of action for any antineoplastic drugs.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin works by forming interstrand DNA cross-links, which lead to DNA damage and cell death. It is commonly used in the treatment of head and neck squamous cell carcinoma, as in this case. The other options, inhibition of polymerization of tubulin, inhibition of topoisomerase 2, and free radical-mediated lipid peroxidation, are mechanisms of action of other antineoplastic drugs but not cisplatin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin is known to form interstrand DNA cross-links, which leads to inhibition of DNA synthesis and subsequent cell death. None of the other options are mechanisms of action of cisplatin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin is known to form interstrand DNA cross-links, which can lead to cell death in rapidly dividing cells such as cancer cells. The other options’ mechanisms of action are not associated with cisplatin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Cisplatin forms interstrand DNA cross-links, which inhibit DNA replication and lead to cell death. This mechanism of action is effective in treating many types of cancer, including squamous cell carcinoma. The other options describe mechanisms of action of other types of chemotherapeutic agents.
